text:
Budget friendly, perfect location , all pubs and party place just 1 min walk away also near to Ella train station.
Staff is very friendly and respectful.

Ravana's Cave is one of those places where the legend is far more captivating than the actual site itself. Tucked away in the hills near Ella, it‚Äôs steeped in the ancient lore of the Ramayana, believed to be one of the hideouts where King Ravana kept Princess Sita captive. This mythological connection is what drew me in, offering a chance to walk through a piece of living history.
The adventure begins with a moderately challenging climb‚Äîaround 650 to 700 steps that wind steeply up through a lush, green forest. The ascent is shaded, which helps with the heat, and you get some genuinely beautiful views of the valley and Little Adam's Peak across the way on your trek up. It's a solid little workout, filled with natural beauty and the chance to spot some local wildlife like monkeys and exotic birds.
However, the "cave" at the top is a bit underwhelming. It's essentially a large, dark opening in the rock face, and you can only go a short distance inside before a barricade stops you. It‚Äôs very dark, damp, and home to many bats, and there is virtually no historical information provided on-site. Most visitors, myself included, find the journey and the surrounding natural views more rewarding than the cave itself. It's a quick stop‚Äîabout an hour round trip‚Äîand best for those who really appreciate the mythology and enjoy a short, steep hike, rather than a significant landmark or panoramic viewpoint. Be sure to bring a torch for the inside of the cave!

We had an amazing afternoon cooking with Sadamali and using the traditional tools. She is happy to answer all your questions and guides you step by step, engaging you to the cooking process. The food she/we prepared was the best we've had in Sri Lanka, especially after her adjusting the spiciness level to our standards. It was the first cooking lesson I ' ve ever had and I really enjoyed every moment!

Our stay at Moonstone Hotel in Anuradhapura was nothing short of amazing. We arrived there at 4.30 a.m. in the middle of a stressful flood situation, and the staff welcomed us with genuine kindness, opening their gates without hesitation and even serving us warm tea. Their friendliness and guest-friendly nature made us feel safe and cared for during a very difficult time.

The rooms were peaceful with zero disturbances, the food was delicious, and the prices were very reasonable. What we loved the most was how homely the entire place felt.

Another huge plus is the location. Moonstone Hotel is conveniently close to major religious sites like Ruwanweli Maha Seya and Sri Maha Bodhi, making it perfect for anyone visiting Anuradhapura.

Highly recommended for anyone looking for comfort, kindness, and a warm, welcoming stay.

Experience the Timeless Grandeur

On November 21st 2025, thirteen of us travelling with Flamingo Lanka visited the sacred Ruwanweliseya stupa.  This remarkable hemispherical monument, originally constructed in 140 BC by king Dutugemunu, stands as one of the tallest ancient structures in the world at a height of 103 metres, with a circumference of 290 metres and housing and enshrines a large amount of Buddha‚Äôs relics within.  Although king Dutugemunu commenced its construction, it was completed after he passed away.

The Ruwanweliseya, constructed primarily of brick, is a marvel of ancient engineering.  The sheer volume of bricks required for its construction is staggering.  Its iconic white appearance is maintained by periodic painting of the outer plaster.  It is a living shrine that had been drawing pilgrims and awe-struck visitors for centuries!

During our visit there, we joined the many devotees venerating and worshipping the stupa.  As is customary at religious sites, visitors are required to dress modestly and remove their footwear before entry.

Ruwanweliseya is open to pilgrims and visitors throughout the day.
Good for joining

Darme is a wonderful Tuk Tuk driver. :) we went from Anuradhapura to Mihintale. Darme showed me wonderful places along the way and informed me about the area.
I always felt safe and we had fun together :)

At Issarasamanaramaya : Sinhala Bodhivamsa identifies this name as Kasungiri Vehera. However, this is the ancient Isurumuniya, which is now known as Vessagiriya in Anuradhapura.

Ashta Pala Bodhi Trees in Sri Lanka

According to the historic Mahavamsa, of the first eight saplings that grew out of the Sri Maha Bodhi (Ashta Pala Bodhi), King Devanampiyatissa planted one at Issarasamanaramaya. Therefore the site known as Vessagiriya today is one of the sites in which an Ashtapala Bodhi was planted.

A decent place for small kids to enjoy, but can feep monotonous for adults. There are multiple rides, and some of them are alike. The pirateship is decent. There are two packages available each for kids and adults. Any additional ride costs Rs.700.

The arcade games look dated and they need to upgrade the games available. The bowling alley is ok.

The snow world during Christmas time is a decent experience for the kids. Entrance for adults is Rs.1600 and kids from 3 to 10 years are charged Rs.1000. They also had a zipline arranged that goes around 50 meters. The cafe has extremely limited food options.

We had an amazing experience with this travel agency during our trip to Malaysia. From start to finish, everything was perfectly organized. The ticket prices were very affordable, and our visas were handled smoothly without any hassle. Every detail from bookings to travel arrangements was well planned and sorted out in advance. We truly felt taken care of throughout the entire journey. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a stress-free and well coordinated travel experience!

Total waste of time. The casino is extremely small and filled with old, outdated slot machines. It looks like they purchase discarded machines from larger, well-known casinos whenever those places upgrade to newer cabinets. Overall, a very disappointing experience.

Good location, Friendly staff‚Ä¶ One of the Best Casinos in Colombo.

A racist, a scammer, and an abuser of power who forcibly detained meü§¢

I am writing this complaint with great anger regarding what happened to me tonight (Dec 9, around 7:44 PM) at your Asian restaurant. I am a regular customer who has brought many friends here, but today I was treated like a criminal by your waiter Robin (photo attached).

1. Harassment and Detention

While I was eating, Robin kept aggressively demanding payment. I refused to give him cash at the table because he was acting so shady that I suspected he wanted to pocket the money himself.

Because I wouldn't pay him cash directly, he blocked me and refused to let me leave for 10 minutes. He only let me go downstairs to the cashier after I screamed that I would call the police.

2. Public Humiliation

This scene caused a huge commotion. Many other Chinese guests gathered to watch me being detained. This was incredibly humiliating and has damaged my reputation in front of my community.

3. The Scam

At the cashier, I handed over 10,000 LKR specifically to buy chips. Robin tricked the cashier into charging me 7,500 LKR for a buffet instead. I never agreed to this charge. I wanted chips. I was scammed.

4. Racism

I believe Robin targeted me specifically because I am Chinese. The manager on duty did nothing to help and covered up for him.

I demand a refund of my 7,500 LKR in chips and an investigation into Robin immediately.

If you do not fix this, I will post the full story of this racism and scam on all Chinese social media platforms. Please wait and see, the result will come very soon.

On top of that, Robin actually tried to physically snatch my payment receipt and my mobile phone from my hands. I felt genuinely threatened and scared.

Is this behavior allowed in your employee handbook? Snatching a proof of payment from a customer? Oh my god, this is absolutely insane.

I will definitely be filing a formal report about this to the Sri Lankan government authorities!!!!!!!!!!
Good food and service. Rooms are worth the price. Meals are also very worth the price and tasty

We recently booked a trip to the Sinharaja Forest with this company, and the experience was truly outstanding.
The communication from the company was excellent from start to finish. Our driver was incredibly kind, attentive to all our requests, and drove exceptionally well and safely.
The guide in the forest was very observant, patient, showed us everything of interest, and even offered us homemade food, which was a lovely, personal touch.
On the way back, we stopped at a brilliant tea factory that was fascinating and very interesting. We appreciated that no one pressured us for a tip, but we were so satisfied with the service that we happily gave.
We would absolutely choose this company again for our next trip!

I visited the Maritime Museum for the first time and had a wonderful experience! The exhibits are fascinating and well-presented, giving a great insight into Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich maritime history. The displays are informative and easy to understand, and the staff are friendly and helpful. The atmosphere is calm, clean, and well-maintained, making it enjoyable to explore at your own pace. A must-visit spot for history lovers and anyone interested in the sea!

One of the best temples to truly experience the divine presence of Lord Murugan.
When the Pooja begins at 5:30 PM, it starts with traditional and devotional music that instantly elevates your spirit. For a few moments, you‚Äôll feel as if you‚Äôve stepped into heaven.
Just visit once and experience it yourself!

visited Richmond Castle in Kalutara around mid-morning, which turned out to be the perfect time. The grounds were peaceful, with soft sunlight filtering through the trees, enhancing the beauty of the colonial architecture. This early 1900s mansion, once the home of a wealthy Sri Lankan philanthropist, is a stunning example of Indo-Saracenic design, with intricately carved woodwork, stained glass windows from Scotland, and a fascinating blend of Eastern and Western influences

We visited Richmond Castle over the weekend, and it was a really interesting experience. You have to buy tickets at the entrance, and once you step inside, the architecture immediately catches your eye. The place has a unique charm and a lot of history behind it. If you enjoy old buildings and stories from the past, you‚Äôll definitely find it worth the visit. The castle is quite old and a bit fragile, so you need to be careful when walking around. Overall, it‚Äôs a spot I‚Äôd say everyone should check out at least once.

Visiting Kalutara Bodhiya was a peaceful and memorable experience. This sacred place has a calm and spiritual atmosphere that makes you feel relaxed the moment you enter the premises. The area is very well maintained, and the surrounding environment feels clean, serene, and welcoming to anyone seeking a quiet moment for prayer or reflection. The stupa itself is beautiful and impressive, and the fact that it is located so close to the river adds to the charm and uniqueness of the site.

One thing I really appreciated was how organized everything was. There are clear pathways, proper places to offer flowers, and volunteers who help guide visitors respectfully. Even when the crowd gets a little busy, it still manages to maintain a peaceful ambiance. The large Bo tree area is especially calming, with the soft sound of the wind and bells creating a soothing spiritual feeling.

Parking is generally convenient, and there are small shops nearby where you can buy flowers and other offerings at reasonable prices. I also noticed that the environment is kept clean, which makes the overall experience even better. Whether you are visiting for religious purposes or just to enjoy a bit of quiet time, Kalutara Bodhiya is definitely worth the stop. It‚Äôs a place that gives you both mental peace and a beautiful cultural experience.

Kalutara bodhiya is one of my favorite places to visit Everytime I come to the Area. Temple is easily accessible and plenty of parking available separately. (You need to walk over the Mahanama Bridge though) Dagaba is one of a kind design in Sri Lankan Engineering.

Sri Dalada Maligawa, located in the historic city of Kandy, is one of the most sacred and important religious sites in Sri Lanka. The temple is believed to house the Sacred Tooth Relic of Lord Buddha, making it a major pilgrimage destination for Buddhists from around the world. Every day, thousands of devotees visit the temple to offer prayers and experience its peaceful spiritual atmosphere.

The temple complex showcases beautiful Kandyan architecture, with detailed wood carvings, stone work, and traditional murals that reflect Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich cultural heritage. The surroundings are calm and well maintained, creating a serene environment despite the large number of visitors. The nearby Kandy Lake adds extra beauty to the area and is ideal for photography.

One of the most famous events held here is the annual Esala Perahera, a grand cultural procession featuring traditional dancers, drummers, fire performers, and beautifully decorated elephants. This event attracts both local and international tourists.

Sri Dalada Maligawa is not only a place of worship but also a symbol of Sri Lanka‚Äôs history, culture, and religious harmony. It is truly a must-visit destination for anyone visiting Kandy. üåøüìø

this era Kandy was called as Senkadagala. This name came into being due to a Brahmin named Senkanda, who lived in a cave at Udawattakele during that era. During the Kandyan Kingdom, this forest area behind the palace was called Uda wasala watta or the 'Upper Palace Garden' frequented by the royalty and was out of bound to the people. Since the downfall of the Kandyan Kingdom in 1815, this forest area started to loose it's pristine condition due to wood cutting etc.

The condition of the forest deteriorated due to human activities and in 1856, the Government declared it as a Forest Reserve and later in 1938, it was made a sanctuary. The Kandy Lake gets it's water resourses mainly from this forest's catchment areas. This precious forest area supplies the much needed air purification activity to the Kandy city which is enclaved by several hills.

Uh...shouldn't the International Buddhist Museum mention the most influential Buddhist in the world (The Dalai Lama)? For someone who knows very little about Buddhism and was hoping for a thoughtful introduction, this was a disappointing experience. It's a haphazard collection that includes what appears to be a CCP-sponsored whitewashing of the Tibetan experience.
Despite the first couple of galleries being a little anonymous, I found this museum to "grow" room after room. It offers a great panoramic on Buddhism worldwide and it's very informative.

I was there with my family on half board basis for two nights. Below are our firsthand experiences.
1. Don‚Äôt get lured by the outlook/profile photos & descriptions which are very old. This place has seen its better days.
2. Charges cannot be justified & it is way too high for that shoddy arrangement which they claim a 3-star hotel.
3. No responsible officer on the property to take care of the guests in case of emergency situation during after hours, let aside an operational front desk.
4. No telephone/ intercom system. Only an unconnected CDMA telephone was in the rooms. Only God knows how to communicate using that.
5. Cannot safely access dining area which is an open space, & you are compelled to brave all risks of security and weather in getting there.
6. All cutlery continued to be laid full time, even during the night till next day‚Äôs breakfast. Unsuspecting diners use those without knowing which rat or raccoon licked or rubbed their genitalia on those.
7. No loading/unloading area.
8. No disabled access.
9. No covered access to rooms. Hell on earth when raining.
10. Risk of flooding.
11. Only positive thing noted was food, that was acceptable, that too without knowing the kitchen condition and other practices followed.
12. All-in-all we would rate this place 1 in a scale of 5 if not 0.

One of the best hotels I‚Äôve stayed in. The environment was very calming and the staff was the best. Moreover, the food was superb, and super delicious. I highly recommend you the place and will surely visit next time.

Thirukoneswaram Kovil in Trincomalee, also known as the Temple of a Thousand Pillars, is one of the most revered Hindu temples in Sri Lanka and holds a prominent place in Ramayana legend. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is believed to be linked to Ravana and his devotion to Shiva. Thirukoneswaram is often referred to as the Dakshina Kailasa (Southern Kailash) and is revered for its spiritual energy and significance in Shaivism.

According to local lore, Ravana was a devout follower of Lord Shiva, and it‚Äôs said that he visited the Thirukoneswaram temple to offer prayers and seek blessings. The Yuddha Kanda of the Ramayana speaks of Ravana‚Äôs worship of Shiva, but it doesn‚Äôt specify the location. In Sri Lankan tradition, Thirukoneswaram is considered one of the places where Ravana‚Äôs deep devotion to Shiva was evident.

It is believed that Ravana installed a lingam (a representation of Shiva) at Thirukoneswaram as part of his devotion. According to Sri Lankan lore, he would come here to perform rituals and pray for strength, which was part of his effort to gain divine protection and powers. Some legends even suggest that he meditated here, hoping to obtain boons from Shiva to fortify his strength for battles.

Another legend holds that after defeating Ravana, Rama himself visited Thirukoneswaram to atone for the sin of killing Ravana, who, despite his wrongdoings, was a Brahmin and a devotee of Shiva. This belief aligns with the tradition that Rama traveled to several Shiva temples to cleanse himself of the ‚ÄúBrahmahatya dosha‚Äù (the sin of killing a Brahmin).
